intro: Ceropegia seshachalamensis, commonly known as the Seshachalam moonvine, is a flowering plant native to the Indian subcontinent. It belongs to the family Apocynaceae and is characterized by its trailing growth habit and tuberous roots. The plant produces small, tubular flowers that are typically white or pale green, often with a distinctive hood-like structure. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, showcasing adaptations to drought conditions. Due to its limited distribution and unique morphology, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists.
